sen.j: 旗本（はたもと）とは、主として江戸時代に徳川将軍家直属の家臣団のうち、石高が1万石未満で儀式などで将軍が出席する席に参列する御目見以上の家格をもつものの総称。
sen.e: The term of Hatamoto indicates totally the persons who were direct retainers of the Tokugawa shogun family, were provided with an amount of rice crop less than 10,000 koku (approx. 180 liters/koku), and were provided with the family status to be allowed to have an audience with the shogun.

The "hatamoto" is a general term indicating those who were direct retainers of the Tokugawa shogun family, provided with an amount of rice crop less than 10,000 koku (approximately 180 liters/koku) and the family status of omemie (vassal with the privilege to have an audience with the shogun) or higher who attended the ceremonies in the shogun's presence.
sen.cmt: 「儀式などで将軍が出席する席に参列する」訳漏れのため、全文修正して対応しました。
sen.e: The "hatamoto" is a general term indicating those who were direct retainers of the Tokugawa shogun family, provided with an amount of rice crop less than 10,000 koku (approximately 180 liters/koku) and the family status of omemie (vassal with the privilege to have an audience with the shogun) or higher who attended the ceremonies in the shogun's presence.

sen.j: もとは戦場で主君の軍旗を守る武士団を意味しており、徳川氏時代のみの制度ではない。
sen.e: This term originally indicated a samurai group who guarded the battle flag of their lord in war areas, and Hatamoto retainers existed in eras other than the Tokugawa period as well.
Since it originally used to indicate a samurai group who guarded the battle flag of their lord in war areas, it is not a system only in Tokugawa period.
Since it originally used to indicate a samurai group who guarded the battle flag of their lord in war areas, it is not a system only in Tokugawa period.

tit.e: Hatamoto in the Sengoku period (period of warring states)
Hatamoto in the Sengoku period (period of warring states)
Hatamoto in the Sengoku period (period of warring states)

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には、国人等の独立的軍団を構成している幕下層（家臣ではないが臣下の礼をとり軍事的に従属）とは別に、主君の指揮下に属する直属部隊の家臣を指す場合もある。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (in Japan), this term was sometimes used for indicating the retainers who were under direct control of a lord, to separate them from the makusita-so samurai belonging to an independent samurai group, for example, a group called Kokujin (who were not retainers of the lord but were subordinated to the lord militarily).
sen.cmt: 幕下層： 正しい読み、不明です。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (Japan), this term sometimes indicated the retainers who were under direct control of a lord, to separate them from the makusita-so samurai belonging to an independent military service such as kokujin (who were not retainers of the lord but were subordinated to the lord militarily).
sen.cmt: 全文修正しました。※ウィキペディアの原文では「国人」ではなく「国人領主」となっています。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (Japan), this term sometimes indicated the retainers who were under direct control of a lord, to separate them from the makusita-so samurai belonging to an independent military service such as kokujin (who were not retainers of the lord but were subordinated to the lord militarily).

sen.j: とくに譜代の家臣を中心に編成され、戦闘時には、主君の本陣備を構成した。
sen.e: Hatamoto was organized mostly by the retainers whose families had served the lord family for generations, and constituted the samurai group for guarding the main war base of the lord in fighting.
sen.cmt: 備： ウェッブ上の表現ない合わせ、”本陣備"に変更した上で訳してあります。
sen.e: Hatamoto was organized mostly by hereditary vassals, and constituted the samurai group for guarding the main war base of the lord in fighting.
sen.cmt: the retainers whose families had served the lord family for generations をhereditary vassals に修正しました。
sen.e: Hatamoto was organized mostly by hereditary vassals, and constituted the samurai group for guarding the main war base of the lord in fighting.

sen.j: 当時は、幕下の礼をとり家臣の立場にあったが領国経営では独立していた国人領主層の離合集散が当然のように行なわれていた。
sen.e: In the era, the Kokujin territory owners, who were subordinated to a lord but controlled their territories independently, were aligned and realigned with each other freely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At that time, the local samurai lords who were subordinated to a lord but controlled their territories independently aligned and realigned with each other freely.
At that time, the local samurai lords who were subordinated to a lord but controlled their territories independently aligned and realigned with each other freely.

sen.j: そのような背景から、主君からすれば、直属の旗本家臣団への信頼は極めて強く、国政にも中心的に関与したと見られる。
sen.e: Under such a background, it is considered that lords relied on the Hatamoto retainers strongly and that the Hatamoto retainers were involved in the governments centrally.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Under such a background, it is considered that lords relied on the hatamoto strongly and that the hatamoto were involved in the governments centrally.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。
sen.e: Under such a background, it is considered that lords relied on the hatamoto strongly and that the hatamoto were involved in the governments centrally.

sen.j: 例えば上杉謙信の家臣の千坂景親のように戦闘時に常に本陣周辺に配置されるため、華々しい戦果を残すことはあまりないが、戦国時代の家臣団の中枢を担うのは、この旗本家臣層にあったといっても過言ではない。
sen.e: It would not be too much to say that, of the retainers, Hatamoto retainers played the central role in the Sengoku period, although they could not attain brilliant military achievements, because they, for example, Kagechika CHIZAKA (CHISAKA), a retainer of Kenshin UESUGI, were deployed around the main war base in fighting..

It would not be too much to say that, of the retainers, the hatamoto played the central role in the Sengoku period, although they could not attain brilliant military achievements, because they, for example, Kagechika CHIZAKA (CHISAKA), a retainer of Kenshin UESUGI, were deployed around the main war base in fighting..
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。
sen.e: It would not be too much to say that, of the retainers, the hatamoto played the central role in the Sengoku period, although they could not attain brilliant military achievements, because they, for example, Kagechika CHIZAKA (CHISAKA), a retainer of Kenshin UESUGI, were deployed around the main war base in fighting..

tit.e: Hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)
Hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)
Hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

sen.j: 江戸時代の旗本は、三河から勃興した徳川氏の家臣が代表的である。
sen.e: Typical examples of Hatamoto in the Edo period, were retainers of the Tokugawa clan who originated in the Mikawa area.
Typical examples of hatamoto in the Edo period were retainers of the Tokugawa clan who originated in Mikawa.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。period, のカンマを削除しました。in the Mikawa area を in Mikawa に修正しました。
sen.e: Typical examples of hatamoto in the Edo period were retainers of the Tokugawa clan who originated in Mikawa.

sen.j: ほかに後北条氏、武田氏、今川氏の遺臣、大名の一族や、改易大名の名跡を継ぐ者、遠隔地の豪族で大名になりきれなかった名族、かつて戦国大名や、守護大名などであった赤松氏、畠山氏、別所氏、北条、富樫氏、最上氏、山名氏、武田、今川、大友氏、織田氏、金森氏、滝川氏、筒井氏、土岐氏、福島正則の嫡流、庶流の末裔などから構成されている。
sen.e: In addition, Hatamoto also included surviving vassals of the Gohojo clan and of the Takeda clan, and the Akamatsu clan, the Hatakeyama clan, the Bessho clan, the Hojo clan, the Togashi clan, Mogami clan, the Yamana clan, the Takeda clan, the Imagawa clan, the Otomo clan, the Oda clan, the Kanamori clan, the Takigawa clan, the Tsutsui clan, the Toki clan, and the direct descendant families of and the branch families of Masanori FUKUSHIMA, all of whom were a daimyo family, the person succeeding the name of daimyo whose properties had been confiscated, a noble family that was a powerful clan in a remote area and could not become a daimyo, a former daimyo in the Sengoku period, or a shugo daimyo (a daimyo who became a daimyo from shugo (a Japanese provincial military governor)).

In addition, hatamoto also included surviving vassals of the Gohojo clan and of the Takeda clan, and the Akamatsu clan, the Hatakeyama clan, the Bessho clan, the Hojo clan, the Togashi clan, the Mogami clan, the Yamana clan, the Takeda clan, the Imagawa clan, the Otomo clan, the Oda clan, the Kanamori clan, the Takigawa clan, the Tsutsui clan, the Toki clan, and the direct descendant families of and the branch families of Masanori FUKUSHIMA, all of whom were a daimyo family, the person succeeding the name of daimyo whose properties had been confiscated, a noble family that was a powerful clan in a remote area and could not become a daimyo, a former daimyo in the Sengoku period, or a shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).
sen.cmt: Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。Mogami clan に the を追記しました。(a daimyo who became a daimyo from shugo (a Japanese provincial military governor)) を(shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords) に修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, hatamoto also included surviving vassals of the Gohojo clan and of the Takeda clan, and the Akamatsu clan, the Hatakeyama clan, the Bessho clan, the Hojo clan, the Togashi clan, the Mogami clan, the Yamana clan, the Takeda clan, the Imagawa clan, the Otomo clan, the Oda clan, the Kanamori clan, the Takigawa clan, the Tsutsui clan, the Toki clan, and the direct descendant families of and the branch families of Masanori FUKUSHIMA, all of whom were a daimyo family, the person succeeding the name of daimyo whose properties had been confiscated, a noble family that was a powerful clan in a remote area and could not become a daimyo, a former daimyo in the Sengoku period, or a shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).

sen.j: 石高が8,000石前後で大名待遇の家格を持つ「大身旗本」及び、徳川将軍家の本家筋に当たる松平郷松平家（420石）は、交代寄合と呼ばれた。
sen.e: "Taishin-Hatamoto," who earned a rice crop of around 8,000 koku and was provided with a family status treated daimyo as well, and the Matsudaira family in the Matsudaira-go area (with a 420 koku of rice crop), where the Tokugawa shogun family originated, were called Kotai-yoriai.

Taishin-Hatamoto,' who earned a rice crop of around 8,000 koku and was provided with a family status treated daimyo as well, and the Matsudaira family in the Matsudaira-go area (with a 420 koku of rice crop), where the Tokugawa shogun family originated, were called Kotai-yoriai.
sen.cmt: ダブルコーテーションをシングルコーテーションに修正しました。
sen.e: Taishin-Hatamoto,' who earned a rice crop of around 8,000 koku and was provided with a family status treated daimyo as well, and the Matsudaira family in the Matsudaira-go area (with a 420 koku of rice crop), where the Tokugawa shogun family originated, were called Kotai-yoriai.

sen.j: 儀礼等を司る役目を負う吉良氏・畠山・今川・武田等の旧名門の家格出身者は家臣団とは別格の高家と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In addition to the Kira family in charge of etiquette, the families from the former noble clans, such as the Hatakeyama clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Takeda clan, were called Koke (literally, high-level family), being separated from other retainers

Those who were from the families of former noble clans and responsible for protocol, such as the Kira clan, the Hatakeyama clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Takeda clan were called koke (master of ceremonies) and separated from other retainers.

Those who were from the families of former noble clans and responsible for protocol, such as the Kira clan, the Hatakeyama clan, the Imagawa clan, and the Takeda clan were called koke (master of ceremonies) and separated from other retainers.

sen.j: 高家ははじめ吉良家など3家であったが、次第に増加して26家となった。
sen.e: Initially, the number of koke families was three, including the Kira family, but gradually increased up to 26.
Initially, the number of koke families including the Kira family was three, but gradually increased up to 26.
sen.cmt: 語順を入れ替えました。
sen.e: Initially, the number of koke families including the Kira family was three, but gradually increased up to 26.

sen.j: 高家は1,000石級の者が多く、家柄や官位に比して、家禄は少ないことが多い。
sen.e: Being mostly provided with the rice crop of around 1,000 koku, the earnings of these Koke families were often smaller, compared with their family statuses or their governmental post levels.
Being mostly provided with the rice crop of around 1,000 koku, the earnings of these koke were often smaller compared with their family statuses or their governmental post levels.
sen.cmt: Koke families を koke に修正しました。Smaller, のカンマを削除しました。
sen.e: Being mostly provided with the rice crop of around 1,000 koku, the earnings of these koke were often smaller compared with their family statuses or their governmental post levels.

sen.j: 高家肝煎は、10万石級の大名と同じ官位が与えられることもあったが、石高は最高でも5,000石未満であった。
sen.e: Governmental posts that should be given to a 100,000-koku class daimyo were sometimes given to Koke-kimoiri families (dominant families of the Koke families), but their earnings were always less than 5,000 koku.

Governmental posts that should be given to a 100,000-koku class daimyo were sometimes given to koke-kimoiri (dominant families of the koke families), but their earnings were always less than 5,000 koku.
sen.cmt: Koke-kimoiri families を koke kimoiri に修正しました。
sen.e: Governmental posts that should be given to a 100,000-koku class daimyo were sometimes given to koke-kimoiri (dominant families of the koke families), but their earnings were always less than 5,000 koku.

sen.j: 御目見以下の家格の者は御家人と呼ばれた。
sen.e: The retainers who were not allowed to have an audience with Shogun were called Gokenin.
The retainers who belonged to the social standing of omemie (vassal with the privilege to have an audience with the shogun or under that were called "gokenin" (immediate vassal of the shogunate).
The retainers who belonged to the social standing of omemie (vassal with the privilege to have an audience with the shogun or under that were called "gokenin" (immediate vassal of the shogunate).

sen.j: 旗本の生活
sen.e: Lives of Hatamoto
Life of Hatamoto
sen.cmt: Lives を Life に修正しました。
sen.e: Life of Hatamoto

sen.j: 旗本・御家人は武家諸法度により統制され、若年寄の支配下におかれた。
sen.e: Hatamoto and Gokenin were governed by Buke shohatto (laws for the samurai families), and were placed under control of Wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in the Edo bakufu).
Hatamoto and Gokenin were governed by Buke shohatto (Laws for the Military Houses), and were placed under control of wakadoshiyori (junior councilor).
sen.cmt: Gokenin を gokenin に修正しました。 laws for the samurai families をLaws for the Military Houses に修正しました。Wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in the Edo bakufu) をwakadoshiyori (junior councilor) に修正しました。
sen.e: Hatamoto and Gokenin were governed by Buke shohatto (Laws for the Military Houses), and were placed under control of wakadoshiyori (junior councilor).

sen.j: 江戸集住（定府）が原則で、交代寄合には知行所に陣屋が与えられた。
sen.e: They had to reside basically in Edo, but the Kotai-yoriai families were provided with a jinya (a regional government office) in their chigyosho (the territories they governed).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They had to reside basically in Edo, but the Kotai-yoriai families were provided with a jinya (a regional government office) in their chigyosho (hatamoto's fief).
sen.cmt: a regional の a を削除しました。the territories they governed を hatamoto's fief に修正しました。※出典：http://books.google.com/books?id=j3kjAxhbjDAC&q=chigyosho&dq=chigyosho&hl=ja&ei=gXdjTPWOGYy0vgPhq8GeCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBjgK
sen.e: They had to reside basically in Edo, but the Kotai-yoriai families were provided with a jinya (a regional government office) in their chigyosho (hatamoto's fief).

sen.j: 一般には3,000石以上の旗本（旗本寄合席）には大名に準じた知行権（統治権）を有して死刑などの重刑裁判以外の行政権・司法権を行使した。
sen.e: Generally, the Hatamoto retainers with the rice crop of 3,000 koku or more were provided with the Chigyo (governing) right in their territories and were entitled to execute administrative rights and judicial rights there, except trials for grave penalty.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Generally, the hatamoto with the rice crop of 3,000 koku or more (hatamoto yoriaiseki [a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto, direct vassal of the shogun]) were provided with the right to manage their fief like daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), and executed administrative rights and judicial rights except trials for grave penalty such as death penalty.
sen.cmt: 「大名に準じた」、「死刑などの」訳漏れのため、全文修正して対応しました。
sen.e: Generally, the hatamoto with the rice crop of 3,000 koku or more (hatamoto yoriaiseki [a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto, direct vassal of the shogun]) were provided with the right to manage their fief like daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), and executed administrative rights and judicial rights except trials for grave penalty such as death penalty.

sen.j: 大部分を占めた500石以下は徴租権（年貢の納入）以外の知行権は幕府の代官または郡代に委任される事になっていた。
sen.e: For the Hatamoto retainers with 500 koku or less, who constituted most of Hatamoto, the chigyo rights, except collecting tax, were entrusted to governmental officers of the bakuku, called Daikan or Gundai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For the hatamoto with 500 koku or less, who constituted most of hatamoto, the right to manage their fief except collecting tax, were entrusted to governmental officers of the bakuku, called Daikan or Gundai.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。chigyo rights を right to manage their fief に修正しました。
sen.e: For the hatamoto with 500 koku or less, who constituted most of hatamoto, the right to manage their fief except collecting tax, were entrusted to governmental officers of the bakuku, called Daikan or Gundai.

sen.j: 幕府は基本的には領主である旗本が知行権を行使することを好まずこれを抑制する方針を取った。
sen.e: The bakufu disliked the execution of chigyo rights by the Hatamoto retainers who possessed their own territories, and took the policy of curbing the execution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The bakufu disliked the execution of right to manage their fief by the Hatamoto retainers who possessed their own territories, and took the policy of curbing the execution.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。chigyo rights を right to manage their fief に修正しました。
sen.e: The bakufu disliked the execution of right to manage their fief by the Hatamoto retainers who possessed their own territories, and took the policy of curbing the execution.

sen.j: しかしながら、税収の確保や領内の不祥事は領主である旗本の責任とされるために、500石以下であっても自らの知行権を積極的に行使する旗本も存在していた。
sen.e: However, because they needed securing tax and were also responsible for scandals in their territories, some Hatamoto retainers executed their chigyo right actively, even though they earned a 500 koku or less of rice crop.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, because they needed securing tax and were also responsible for scandals in their territories, some hatamoto executed their right to manage their fief actively, even though they earned a 500 koku or less of rice crop.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。chigyo rights を right to manage their fief に修正しました。
sen.e: However, because they needed securing tax and were also responsible for scandals in their territories, some hatamoto executed their right to manage their fief actively, even though they earned a 500 koku or less of rice crop.

sen.j: 俗に「旗本八万騎」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: It was commonly said that "the number of the Hatamoto retainers was 80,000."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was commonly said that 'the number of hatamoto was 80,000.'
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。ダブルコーテーションをシングルコーテーションに修正しました。
sen.e: It was commonly said that 'the number of hatamoto was 80,000.'

sen.j: しかしながら、1722年の調査では総数約5,000人、御目見以下の御家人を含めても17,000人の規模であった。
sen.e: However, in a survey in 1722, the number was approx. 5,000, and was 17,000 including even the Gokenin retainers who were not allowed to have an audience with the shogun.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in a survey in 1722, the number was approximately 5,000, and was 17,000 including even the gokenin of omemie or under.
However, in a survey in 1722, the number was approximately 5,000, and was 17,000 including even the gokenin of omemie or under.

sen.j: ただし、旗本・御家人の家臣を含めると、およそ80,000人になると言われている（これに対して10万石の大名に許された兵力は2,155人である）
sen.e: However, it is said that the number became roughly 80,000, when the retainers of Hatamoto and of Gokenin were further included (for this, the number of military personnel allowed for a 100,000-koku daimyo was 2,155).

However, it is said that the number became roughly 80,000, when the retainers of hatamoto and of gokenin were further included (for this, the number of military personnel allowed for a 100,000-koku daimyo was 2,155).
sen.cmt: Hatamoto and Gokenin を hatamoto and gokenin に修正しました。
sen.e: However, it is said that the number became roughly 80,000, when the retainers of hatamoto and of gokenin were further included (for this, the number of military personnel allowed for a 100,000-koku daimyo was 2,155).

sen.j: 旗本で、5,000石以上の者は、交代寄合を含み約100人。
sen.e: The Hatamoto retainers who earned a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop was approx. 100.
The hatamoto who earned a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop including kotai-yoriai was approximately 100.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。「交代寄合を含み」訳漏れのためincluding kotai-yoriai を追記して対応しました。approx. を approximately に修正しました。
sen.e: The hatamoto who earned a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop including kotai-yoriai was approximately 100.

sen.j: 3,000石以上の者は約300人であり、旗本の9割は500石以下である。
sen.e: Those who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop was approx. 300, with a 90%t of Hatamoto earning a 500 koku or less of rice crop..
Those who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop was approximately 300, and 90 percent of hatamoto earned a 500 koku or less of rice crop..
sen.cmt: approx. を approximately に修正しました。後半部を全文修正しました。
sen.e: Those who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop was approximately 300, and 90 percent of hatamoto earned a 500 koku or less of rice crop..

sen.j: なお、宝永年間の記録によれば、旗本の地方高（知行地を与えられていた者の総禄高）は275.4万石で全体の64%を占め、切米・蔵米・扶持受給が石高換算で153.4万石を占めていた。
sen.e: According to a record in the Hoei era (1704 - 1711), the amount of chiho-daka of the Hatamoto retainers (the total earnings of the Hatamoto retainers provided with chigyo-chi (territories)) was a 2,754,000 koku of rice crop, occupying 64% of all earnings of the Hatamoto, with a 1,534,000 koku of rice crop in total given to the Hatamoto retainers with no chigyo-chi as salary called, kirimai, kuramai, or fumochi.

According to a record in the Hoei era (1704 - 1711), the amount of chiho-daka of hatamoto (the total earnings of hatamoto who were granted their chigyo-chi [fief]) was a 2,754,000 koku of rice crop, occupying 64% of all earnings of the hatamoto, and a 1,534,000 koku of rice crop as salary called, kirimai, kuramai (rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains), or fuchi (stipend).

According to a record in the Hoei era (1704 - 1711), the amount of chiho-daka of hatamoto (the total earnings of hatamoto who were granted their chigyo-chi [fief]) was a 2,754,000 koku of rice crop, occupying 64% of all earnings of the hatamoto, and a 1,534,000 koku of rice crop as salary called, kirimai, kuramai (rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains), or fuchi (stipend).

sen.j: 知行地は全国に広がっているものの、関東地方が全体の8割を占め、特に江戸のある武蔵国が全国の旗本知行地の21％、近隣の上総国が12.5%、下総国が11.0％を占めていた。
sen.e: Although the chigyo-chi existed throughout the nation, 80 % of it was concentrated in the Kanto region, in particular, with 21% of all Hatamoto chigyo-chi in the Musashi province where Edo was located, 12.5 % in the neighboring Kazusa province, and 11% in the Shimosa province.

Although the chigyo-chi existed throughout the nation, 80 % of it was concentrated in the Kanto region, in particular, with 21% of all Hatamoto chigyo-chi in the Musashi Province where Edo was located, 12.5 % in the neighboring Kazusa Province, and 11% in the Shimosa Province.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。province を Province に修正しました。
sen.e: Although the chigyo-chi existed throughout the nation, 80 % of it was concentrated in the Kanto region, in particular, with 21% of all Hatamoto chigyo-chi in the Musashi Province where Edo was located, 12.5 % in the neighboring Kazusa Province, and 11% in the Shimosa Province.

sen.j: 旗本は石高が低い割には軍役負担が大きく、また石高調整のために相給が行われる事が多く、極端な場合では13名の旗本が1村を分割知行するなどその支配は困難を極めた。
sen.e: Hatamoto were obliged to bear larger military burden for smaller earnings (the amount of rice crop), and in addition, aikyu practice (dividing control of an area among more than one person) was done to adjust the amounts of rice crop among the Hatamoto retainers: For example, control right of a village was divided among 13 Hatamoto retainers in a particular case, making the control extremely difficult.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hatamoto were obliged to bear larger military burden for smaller earnings (the amount of rice crop), and in addition, aikyu practice (dividing control of an area among more than one person) was done to adjust the amounts of rice crop among the hatamoto: For example, control right of a village was divided among 13 hatamoto in a particular case, making the control extremely difficult.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers を hatamoto に修正しました。
sen.e: Hatamoto were obliged to bear larger military burden for smaller earnings (the amount of rice crop), and in addition, aikyu practice (dividing control of an area among more than one person) was done to adjust the amounts of rice crop among the hatamoto: For example, control right of a village was divided among 13 hatamoto in a particular case, making the control extremely difficult.

sen.j: 更に江戸集住の原則から知行取・蔵米取を問わず早くから消費者化が進んだ。
sen.e: Because, in addition, Hatamoto had to reside basically in Edo, their life styles became more and more like those of consumers regardless of whether they got their earnings from chigyo-chi or as salary.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because, in addition, hatamoto had to reside basically in Edo, their life styles became more and more like those of consumers regardless of whether they were chigyo-tori (recipients of land revenue) or kuramaidori (retainers who received rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains as their salary).
sen.cmt: Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。「蔵米取」訳漏れのため、後半部を全文修正しました。
sen.e: Because, in addition, hatamoto had to reside basically in Edo, their life styles became more and more like those of consumers regardless of whether they were chigyo-tori (recipients of land revenue) or kuramaidori (retainers who received rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains as their salary).

sen.j: 幕府成立から30年後の寛永年間には早くも「旗本の窮乏化」が問題とされている。
sen.e: In as early as in the Kanei era (1624 - 1644) in 30 years after the bakufu was established, "impoverishment of Hatamoro" became a problem.
In as early as in the Kanei era (1624 - 1644) in 30 years after the bakufu was established, 'impoverishment of Hatamoro' became a problem.
sen.cmt: "impoverishment of Hatamoro" を 'impoverishment of hatamoto' に修正しました。
sen.e: In as early as in the Kanei era (1624 - 1644) in 30 years after the bakufu was established, 'impoverishment of Hatamoro' became a problem.

sen.j: 寛政の改革の棄捐令の背景もこうした事情があった。
sen.e: Kienrei (a relief measure to help the Gokenin and Hatamoto who fell into economic difficulties during the Edo period) in the Kansei reforms was enacted under such a situation as well.
Kienrei (a relief measure to help the gokenin and hatamoto who fell into economic difficulties during the Edo period) in the Kansei Reforms was enacted under such a situation as well.
sen.cmt: Gokenin and Hatamoto を gokenin and hatamoto に修正しました。reforms を Reforms に修正しました。
sen.e: Kienrei (a relief measure to help the gokenin and hatamoto who fell into economic difficulties during the Edo period) in the Kansei Reforms was enacted under such a situation as well.

sen.j: また、小禄や無役の旗本は将軍に拝謁の資格があったものの、実際に拝謁できたのは家督相続・跡式相続のときのみであった。
sen.e: Even if having the right to have an audience with the shogun, a Hatamoto retainer actually could have an audience with the shogun only in the occasion of Katoku-sozoku (inheriting the family head post because his father resigned from the post, for example, for his advanced age) or Atoshiki-sozoku (inheriting the family head post because his father died), if he earned a small amount of rice crop or was provided with no post.

Even if having the right to have an audience with the shogun, a hatamoto actually could have an audience with the shogun only in the occasion of succession to family headship or Atoshiki-sozoku (inheriting the family head post because his father died), if he earned a small amount of rice crop or was provided with no post.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainer を hatamoto に修正しました。「家督相続」の訳を用語集の定訳に修正しました。
sen.e: Even if having the right to have an audience with the shogun, a hatamoto actually could have an audience with the shogun only in the occasion of succession to family headship or Atoshiki-sozoku (inheriting the family head post because his father died), if he earned a small amount of rice crop or was provided with no post.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期には無頼化した旗本奴が存在し、男伊達を称して徒党を組み、市井の町奴と対立し、歌舞伎や講談の題材にもなった。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, rowdy Hatamoto retainers called Hatamoto-yakko banded together, calling themselves Otoko-date (persons for defending the lower classes), and confronted rowdy people in the general public, called Machi-yakko.

In the early Edo period, rowdy hatamoto called hatamoto-yakko (servants of the shogun) organized a group, called themselves otokodate (ones who seek to right wrongs), and confronted rowdy people in the general public called machi-yakko (town servants), which was written in kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) or kodan storytelling.
sen.cmt: 「歌舞伎や講談の題材にもなった」訳漏れのため、また、各種用語を定訳に修正し、全文修正して対応しました。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, rowdy hatamoto called hatamoto-yakko (servants of the shogun) organized a group, called themselves otokodate (ones who seek to right wrongs), and confronted rowdy people in the general public called machi-yakko (town servants), which was written in kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) or kodan storytelling.

sen.j: 旗本の役職
sen.e: Governmental posts for Hatamoto
Governmental Posts for Hatamoto
sen.cmt: posts を Posts に修正しました。
sen.e: Governmental Posts for Hatamoto

sen.j: 江戸では江戸城の警備や将軍の護衛を行う大番（番方）、文官（役方、行政・司法・財政を担当）である町奉行・勘定奉行・大目付・目付などの役職についた。
sen.e: In Edo, Hatamoto took the post of Oban (Bankata) for guarding the Edo castle and the shogun, or the Bunkan posts (called Yakukata, being in charge of administration, judicature, or finance), such as Machi-bugyo, Kanjo-bugyo, Ometsuke and Metsuke (for each of these terms, refer to the corresponding item).

In Edo, Hatamoto took the post of Oban (or bankata; great guards) for guarding the Edo-jo Castle and the shogun, or civil officers (or yakugata; in charge of administration, judicature, or finance), such as machi bugyo (town magistrate), kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), ometsuke (inspector general) and metsuke (inspector).
sen.cmt: 用語集に従い、定訳に修正しました。※大目付、目付の定訳出典：http://www.google.com/search?q=metsuke+ometsuke+inspector&hl=ja&tbo=1&tbs=bks%3A1&sa=2
sen.e: In Edo, Hatamoto took the post of Oban (or bankata; great guards) for guarding the Edo-jo Castle and the shogun, or civil officers (or yakugata; in charge of administration, judicature, or finance), such as machi bugyo (town magistrate), kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), ometsuke (inspector general) and metsuke (inspector).

sen.j: 無役の旗本は3,000石以上は旗本寄合席、それ以下は小普請組に編入された。
sen.e: The Hatamoto retainers who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop but were provided with no governmental posts were organized into a group called Hatamoto-yoriaiseki, and those who earned a less than 3,000 koku of rice crop but were provided with no governmental posts were organized into a group called Kobushingumi.

The hatamoto without governmental post who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop were organized into hatamoto yoriaiseki (a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto), and those who earned a less than 3,000 koku of rice crop were organized into a group called Kobushin-gumi (samurai without official appointments who receive small salaries).

The hatamoto without governmental post who earned a 3,000 koku or more of rice crop were organized into hatamoto yoriaiseki (a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto), and those who earned a less than 3,000 koku of rice crop were organized into a group called Kobushin-gumi (samurai without official appointments who receive small salaries).

sen.j: 旗本の最高の役職は江戸城留守居である。
sen.e: The highest post available for a Hatamoto retainer was Rusui (a person representing the shogun during his absence) in the Edo castle.
The highest post available for hatamoto was the keepers of Edo-jo Castle.
The highest post available for hatamoto was the keepers of Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 8代将軍吉宗が御三卿を創設してからは、その家老職も江戸城留守居に準ずる地位とされた。
sen.e: After Yoshimune, the eighth shogun, established gosankyo (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family), the Karo post at these families were considered being equivalent in the status to Rusui in the Edo castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After Yoshimune, the eighth shogun, established the Gosankyo (Three Lords: three junior collateral houses of the Tokugawa family), the position of karo (chief retainers) at these families were considered to be equivalent in the status to the keepers of Edo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: established から先を全文修正しました。
sen.e: After Yoshimune, the eighth shogun, established the Gosankyo (Three Lords: three junior collateral houses of the Tokugawa family), the position of karo (chief retainers) at these families were considered to be equivalent in the status to the keepers of Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: しかしながら、3,000石級の旗本から抜擢されることも珍しくなかった。
sen.e: However, it was not rare that a Hatamoto retainer at the 3,000-koku level was selected for such a post.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it was not rare that a hatamoto at the 3,000-koku level was selected for such a post.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainer を hatamoto に修正しました。
sen.e: However, it was not rare that a hatamoto at the 3,000-koku level was selected for such a post.

sen.j: 御三卿は江戸城内に屋敷を持ち、将軍家の家族として取り扱われた。
sen.e: The gosankyo families had their residences in the Edo castle, and their members were handled as those of the shogun family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Gosankyo had their residences in the Edo-jo Castle, and they were treated as the members of shogun family.
The Gosankyo had their residences in the Edo-jo Castle, and they were treated as the members of shogun family.

sen.j: そのため、御三卿の家老は陪臣ではない。
sen.e: Therefore, the Karo at the gosankyo families were not Baishin (retainers of shogun's retainers).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the Karo of Gosankyo were not baishin (indirect vassal).
sen.cmt: Karo を karo に修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, the Karo of Gosankyo were not baishin (indirect vassal).

sen.j: この他、5,000石以上の大身旗本は、将軍側衆、側御用取次、大番頭、書院番頭、小姓組番頭、駿府城代に就任することができた。
sen.e: In addition, the Taishin-hatamoto retainers with a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop could assume the posts of shogun's sobashu (attendants), of Sobagoyou-toritsugi (the person who relayed messages to shogun), of Oban-gashira (captains of the great guards), of Shoinban-gashira (the chief of military patrol), of Koshokumiban-gashira (the chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun) or of Sunpujo-dai (the person sent to control the Sumpu castle).

In addition, the taishin hatamoto (greater vassal) with a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop could assume the posts of Sobashu (aide of the shogun), Sobagoyo-toritsugi (attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message), Oban gashira (captains of the great guards), Head of military patrol, chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun or the keeper of Sunpo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 用語集の定訳に従い、全文修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, the taishin hatamoto (greater vassal) with a 5,000 koku or more of rice crop could assume the posts of Sobashu (aide of the shogun), Sobagoyo-toritsugi (attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message), Oban gashira (captains of the great guards), Head of military patrol, chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun or the keeper of Sunpo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 幕府が重要都市に置いた遠国奉行は1,000石級の旗本から任じられた。
sen.e: Thousand-koku class Hatamoto retainers were appointed to the ongoku-bugyo (administrators) placed by the bakufu at important cities.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The ongoku-bugyo (magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government) placed by the bakufu at important cities was selected among the thousand-koku class hatamoto.
The ongoku-bugyo (magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government) placed by the bakufu at important cities was selected among the thousand-koku class hatamoto.

sen.j: しかしながら、伏見奉行は譜代大名からも任じられた別格のポストであった。
sen.e: However, Fushimi-bugyo (Bugyo at Fushimi) was an exceptional post to which a Fudai daimyo (who was a retainer of the Tokugawa family from before the Sekigawara war) was appointed as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the Fushimi magistrate was an exceptional post to which a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) was appointed as well.
sen.cmt: Fushimi-bugyo (Bugyo at Fushimi) を Fushimi magistrate に、Fudai daimyo (who was a retainer of the Tokugawa family from before the Sekigawara war) をfudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) に、それぞれ修正しました。
sen.e: However, the Fushimi magistrate was an exceptional post to which a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) was appointed as well.

sen.j: 東海道から京に入る要所であり、大名と朝廷を近づけないために、参勤交代の途中で伏見より京側に進むことは認められていなかった。
sen.e: Fushimi was located at a strategic spot to enter Kyo (Kyoto) from the Tokaido road, and in Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), it was prohibited to proceed to the Kyo side from Fushimi, to prevent daimyo from making contact with the Imperial court.

Fushimi was a key point to enter Kyoto from the Tokai-do Road, and in Sankin-kotai (daimyo's alternate-year residence in Edo), it was prohibited to proceed to the Kyoto side from Fushimi, to prevent daimyo from making contact with the Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 用語集の定訳に従い全文修正しました。
sen.e: Fushimi was a key point to enter Kyoto from the Tokai-do Road, and in Sankin-kotai (daimyo's alternate-year residence in Edo), it was prohibited to proceed to the Kyoto side from Fushimi, to prevent daimyo from making contact with the Imperial court.

sen.j: また、将軍の行幸があった日光奉行も他の遠国奉行よりやや格が高かった。
sen.e: The bugyo (administrator) at Nikko where shogun was used to visit was provided with a status slightly higher than that of other ordinary ongoku-bugyo officers.
The Nikko magistrate where shogun was used to visit was provided with a status slightly higher than that of other ongoku-bugyo.
sen.cmt: 用語集の定訳に従い全文修正しました。
sen.e: The Nikko magistrate where shogun was used to visit was provided with a status slightly higher than that of other ongoku-bugyo.

sen.j: 猟官運動が盛んに行われたのは長崎奉行であり、貿易に絡む賄賂に近い副収入が見込めたことで人気が高かった。
sen.e: The Nagasaki-bugyo post was the most coveted one, because additional income, being close to bribes, was expected in relation with trade, and therefore, various maneuvers were conducted to get the post.

The Nagasaki magistrate post was the most coveted one, because additional income, being close to bribes, was expected in relation with trade, and therefore, various maneuvers were conducted to get the post.
sen.cmt: Nagasaki-bugyo を Nagasaki magistrate に修正しました。
sen.e: The Nagasaki magistrate post was the most coveted one, because additional income, being close to bribes, was expected in relation with trade, and therefore, various maneuvers were conducted to get the post.

sen.j: 長崎奉行となって大きな財産を築いた旗本もいた。
sen.e: Some Hatamoto retainers who became Nagsaki-bugyo established a big fortune.
Some hatamoto who became Nagsaki magistrate established a big fortune.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto retainers who became Nagsaki-bugyo を hatamoto who became Nagasaki magistrate に修正しました。
sen.e: Some hatamoto who became Nagsaki magistrate established a big fortune.

sen.j: 一方、100石から200石程度の小禄の旗本は、小十人の番士、納戸、勘定、代官、広敷、祐筆、同朋頭、甲府勤番支配頭、火之番組頭、学問所勤番組頭、徒（徒士）目付の組頭、数寄屋頭、賄頭、蔵奉行、金奉行、林奉行、普請方下奉行、畳奉行、材木石奉行、具足奉行、弓矢槍奉行、吹上奉行、膳奉行、書物奉行、鉄砲玉薬奉行、寺社奉行吟味物調役、勘定吟味改役、川船改役をはじめとする諸役職についた。
sen.e: On the other hand, the governmental posts assumed by the Hatamoto with a small salary of around 100 koku to 200 koku included the following: a member of Kojunin-ban (Kojunin group), Nando, Kanjo, Daikan, Hiroshiki, Yuhitsu, Doho-gashira, Kofukinban-shihaigashira, Hinoban-kumigashira, Gakumonshokinban-kumigashira, Kumigashira of Kachi-metsuke, Sukiya-gashira, Makanai-gashira, Kura-bugyo, Kane-bugyo, Hayashi-bugyo, Fushinkata-shitabugyo, Tatami-bugyo, Zaimokuishi-bugyo, Gusoku-bugyo, Yumiyayari-bugyo, Fukiage-bugyo, Zen-bugyo, Shomotsu-bugyo, Teppodamayaku-bugyo, Jisha-bugyo-ginmimonoshirabeyaku, Kanjo-ginmi-aratameyaku and Kawabune-aratameyaku.
sen.cmt: ”材木石奉行、弓矢槍奉行、鉄砲玉薬奉行”の正しい読みは確認することが出来ませんでした。
sen.e: On the other hand, the governmental posts assumed by the Hatamoto with a small salary of around 100 koku to 200 koku included the following: a member of Kojunin-ban (Kojunin group), Nando, Kanjo, daikan (local governor), hiroshiki (inner apartment supply officer for Edo-jo Castle), Yuhitsu, Doho-gashira, Kofukinban-shihaigashira, Hinoban-kumigashira, Gakumonshokinban-kumigashira, Kumigashira of Kachi-metsuke, Sukiya-gashira, makanai-gashira (chief of cooks), Kura-bugyo, Kane-bugyo, Hayashi-bugyo, Fushinkata-shitabugyo, Tatami-bugyo, Zaimokuishi-bugyo, Gusoku-bugyo, Yumiyayari-bugyo, Fukiage-bugyo, Zen-bugyo, Shomotsu-bugyo, Teppodamayaku-bugyo, Jisha-bugyo-ginmimonoshirabeyaku, Kanjo-Ginmi-aratame yaku (inspector of the documents inspected by assistant minister of treasury) and Kawabune-aratameyaku.
sen.cmt: Daikan, Hiroshiki を daikan (local governor), hiroshiki (inner apartment supply officer for Edo-jo Castle) に修正しました。Makanai-gashira を makanai-gashira (chief of cooks) に修正しました。Kanjo-ginmi-aratameyaku をKanjo-Ginmi-aratame yaku (inspector of the documents inspected by assistant minister of treasury) に修正しました。
sen.e: On the other hand, the governmental posts assumed by the Hatamoto with a small salary of around 100 koku to 200 koku included the following: a member of Kojunin-ban (Kojunin group), Nando, Kanjo, daikan (local governor), hiroshiki (inner apartment supply officer for Edo-jo Castle), Yuhitsu, Doho-gashira, Kofukinban-shihaigashira, Hinoban-kumigashira, Gakumonshokinban-kumigashira, Kumigashira of Kachi-metsuke, Sukiya-gashira, makanai-gashira (chief of cooks), Kura-bugyo, Kane-bugyo, Hayashi-bugyo, Fushinkata-shitabugyo, Tatami-bugyo, Zaimokuishi-bugyo, Gusoku-bugyo, Yumiyayari-bugyo, Fukiage-bugyo, Zen-bugyo, Shomotsu-bugyo, Teppodamayaku-bugyo, Jisha-bugyo-ginmimonoshirabeyaku, Kanjo-Ginmi-aratame yaku (inspector of the documents inspected by assistant minister of treasury) and Kawabune-aratameyaku.

sen.j: 旗本の下位の役職には御家人が就任することもあった。
sen.e: Some Gokenin retainers assumed lower posts for Hatamoto.
Some gokenin assumed lower posts for hatamoto.
sen.cmt: Gokenin retainers を gokenin に、Hatamoto を hatamoto にそれぞれ修正しました。
sen.e: Some gokenin assumed lower posts for hatamoto.

sen.j: 広敷の役人、賄頭、勘定吟味改役は、小禄の旗本の中から有能な者が選ばれていた。
sen.e: For the posts of Hiroshiki, of Makanai-gashira, and of Kanjo-ginmi-aratameyaku, competent persons of the Hatamoto retainers with a small salary were selected.
Hiroshiki, makanai-gashira, and Kanjo-Ginmi-aratame yaku were selected among the competent hatamoto with small stipend.
Hiroshiki, makanai-gashira, and Kanjo-Ginmi-aratame yaku were selected among the competent hatamoto with small stipend.

sen.j: 江戸時代中期以降になると、軍事・警備部門で御家人から旗本に昇進する例はほとんどなくなった。
sen.e: Entering the middle era of the Edo period, no Gokenin retainer became promoted to Hatamoto in the military and guard spheres.
After the mid-Edo period, no gokenin has promoted to hatamoto in the military and guard spheres.
After the mid-Edo period, no gokenin has promoted to hatamoto in the military and guard spheres.

sen.j: その一方で、広敷や勘定奉行の下役人となり、旗本に昇進した者が出た。
sen.e: On the other hand, some Gokenin retainers who assumed lower-level governmental posts under Hiroshiki or under Kanjo-bugyo became promoted to Hatamoto.

sen.j: 旗本の仕組みに大きな変化を見せるのは、開国日本の開国後の安政3年（1856年）に老中阿部正弘が築地に講武所を開いて、西洋の銃術・砲術を含めた集団戦の訓練を旗本に命じてからである。

tit.j: 江戸幕府の旗本の定義
tit.e: Definitions of Hatamoto in the Edo bakufu
Definitions of Hatamoto in the Edo Bakufu
tit.cmt: bakufu を Bakufu に修正しました。
tit.e: Definitions of Hatamoto in the Edo Bakufu

sen.j: 歴史教科書では、江戸幕府（徳川将軍家）の旗本は1万石未満の将軍直属の家臣で、将軍との謁見資格（御目見得以上）を持つ者と定義されているが、厳密にはそう単純ではない。
sen.e: In historical textbooks, Hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (the Tokugawa shogun family) was defined as the persons who were direct retainers of the shogun with a less than 10,000 koku of rice crop and were entitled to have an audience with the shogun (called "(修正候補なし)), but strictly considered, the situation was not so simple.

In historical textbooks, hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (the Tokugawa shogun family) was defined as the persons who were direct retainers of the shogun with a less than 10,000 koku of rice crop and were entitled to have an audience with the shogun (omemie or higher), but strictly considered, the situation was not so simple.
sen.cmt: Hatamoto を hatamoto に修正しました。called "(修正候補なし) を omemie or higher に修正しました。
sen.e: In historical textbooks, hatamoto in the Edo bakufu (the Tokugawa shogun family) was defined as the persons who were direct retainers of the shogun with a less than 10,000 koku of rice crop and were entitled to have an audience with the shogun (omemie or higher), but strictly considered, the situation was not so simple.

sen.j: 狭義の旗本は、200石（200俵）以上、1万石未満の将軍直属の家臣で、交代寄合、高家、及び1万石未満でありながら大名扱いを受けた喜連川氏を除くということになる。
sen.e: In a narrow sense, Hatamoto indicated direct retainers of the shogun with a 200 koku (200 straw bags) or more but less than 10,000 koku of rice crop, excepting the families with the Kotaiyoriai status, the Koke families and the Kiregawa family that was treated as a daimyo though earned less than a less than 10,000 koku. of rice crop.

sen.cmt: 余分なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 広義の旗本には、狭義の旗本に加えて、200石（200俵）未満で、雪駄履きで馬上となる資格がなく、将軍に謁見できる直参も含まれる。
sen.e: In a broad sense, Hatamoto included, in addition to the Hatamoto in the narrow sense, the direct retainers of shogun who earned less than a less than 200 koku (200 straw bags) of rice crop, wore Setta (Japanese traditional sandals), were not entitled to ride on a horse, but was allowed to have an audience with shogun.

sen.j: また、親藩や譜代大名の家臣は陪臣であるから、将軍に謁見できないのが原則であるが、由緒ある家系に対しては、特別に旗本の格式が与えられることがあった。
sen.e: Being baishin, the retainers of shinpan (the domains whose lords were a relative of the Tokugawa family) and of Fudai daimyo could basically not have an audience with the shogun, but the Hatamoto status was sometimes given to members of the families with a distinguished history.

Also, as the retainers of shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives) and of Fudai daimyo are not direct vassals, they could not have an audience with the shogun basically; however, the hatamoto status was sometimes specially given to members of the families with a distinguished history.

sen.j: この場合、将軍に謁見の資格を持ち、参勤交代のときに関所で下馬することを免除された。
sen.e: Such Hatamoto retainers were entitled to have an audience with the shogun, and was allowed not to alight from a horse at sekisho (checking stations) in sankinkotai occasions.

sen.j: 従って最広義の旗本とは、大名及び、大名の扱いを受ける者以外で、将軍に謁見の資格をある者を指す。
